title-group.article-title: Delayed timing of physical therapy initiation increases the risk of future opioid use in individuals with knee osteoarthritis: a real-world cohort study

article-meta.aff: 2Section of Rheumatology, Department of Medicine, Boston University School of Medicine
3Optum Labs Visiting Scholar, Eden Prairie, MN, USA

author-notes.corresp: Corresponding Author: Deepak Kumar, PT, PhD, Assistant Professor, Physical Therapy & Athletic Training, Boston University, Section of Rheumatology, BU School of Medicine, 635 Commonwealth Ave ∣ Boston, MA 02215, (T) 617.358.3037 ∣ (F) 617.353.9463 ∣ kumard@bu.edu

sec.title: Objective:
sec.p: We assessed whether late vs. early initiation of physical therapy (PT) was related to greater risk of future opioid use in people with knee osteoarthritis (OA) who receive physical therapy.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We used Commercial and Medicare Advantage claims data from1999-2018 from American adults with incident knee OA referred for PT within 1-year of diagnosis. We categorized people as opioid naïve or opioid experienced based on prior prescriptions. We examined the association of timing of PT initiation with any and chronic opioid use over 1 year.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Of the 67,245 individuals with incident knee OA, 35,899 were opioid naïve and 31,346 were opioid experienced. In the opioid naïve group, compared with PT within 1-month, PT 1-<3, 3-<6, 6-<9, 9-12 months from diagnosis was associated with adjusted risk ratio [aRR (95% confidence intervals)] for any opioid use of 1.18 (1.10, 1.28), 1.49 (1.37, 1.61), 1.73 (1.58, 1.89), and 1.93 (1.76, 2.12), respectively; aRR for chronic opioid use were 1.25 (1.01, 1.54), 1.83 (1.48, 2.26), 2.29 (1.82, 2.89), and 2.50 (1.96, 3.19). Results were similar among opioid experienced; aRR for any opioid use were 1.19 (1.14, 1.24), 1.32 (1.26, 1.37), 1.39 (1.32, 1.45), and 1.54 (1.46, 1.61); aRR for chronic opioid use were 1.25 (1.17, 1.34), 1.43 (1.33, 1.54), 1.53 (1.41, 1.66), and 1.65 (1.51, 1.80).

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Compared to PT initiation within 1-month, delayed PT initiation was associated with higher risk of opioid use in people with incident knee OA. The longer the delay in PT initiation, the greater was the risk.
